content.description:
Great Zimbabwe's Walls and Stone Enclosures, Twelfth to Fifteenth Century

The photograph shows walls of two different heights and a taller conical tower.

Each structure is similarly constructed of tightly fitted multicolored stone.

In the left foreground is a short wall.

In the background is a tall, curved stone wall that appears to be at least twice the height of the wall in the foreground.

In the center, in front of the taller wall, is a conical stone tower that appears to be significantly taller than the taller wall. A much smaller conical stone structure sits to the right of the base of the tower.

Trees grow on each side of the tower from the area between the two walls
Robin Smith/Getty Images
content.question:
Using the image, respond to parts A, B, and C.

Describe one important cultural or political function of the structures in the image.
Describe one economic, cultural, or social difference between Great Zimbabwe and another African empire in the same period.
Explain one way the religious or cultural practices of an African empire or its people changed after 1500.
